item.title: Little help please
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:12, topic:61059”][quote author=N00b1 link=topic=88018.msg936893#msg936893 date=1172337133]
9hh lol thanks im going camping now and ill see what i can do when i get home but mopar the

System.out.print(“lalalal %d lalala”, var1); is ok aint it? i seen it on sain greasily.com even know you can do “lololololo " + var1 + " lolololo”
[/quote]

Well, you can put that, but everywhere you use the ‘+’ operator on strings the compiler will replace it with this rather stupid code:

(new StringBuilder(firstString)).append(secondString).append(alltheotherstrings).toString(); [/quote]

String yourName;
System.out.print("Your name is ");
System.out.println(yourName);

no + and no stupid StringBuilder

Read full topic

item.title: Little help please
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:6, topic:61059”]}
System.out.printf(“answer %d”, var1);
else
System.out.printf(“sorry %d is not reconised please enter ether * / - +”, var3);

That is not good.[/quote]

Why not? It is a valid way of doing things. Plus it is a lot more comfortable to someone coming from C

It seems like most of your problems N00b1 come from not escaping special characters in the strings you are looking for, in other words you can’t do “+” because it needs to be “+”

[quote=“http://java.sun.com/products/jndi/tutorial/beyond/names/syntax.html”]If one of the following characters appears in the name, then it must be preceded by the escape character, the backslash character (""):

[]A space or “#” character occurring at the beginning of the string
[]A space character occurring at the end of the string
[*]One of the characters “,”, “+”, “”", “”, “<”, “>” or “;”[/quote]

Also, just fyi the normal way we print in java instead of doing:

System.out.printf("sorry %d is not reconised please enter ether * / - +", var3);

to do:

System.out.println("sorry "+var3+" is not reconised please enter ether * / - +");

Read full topic

@N00b1 wrote:

oh they are print f wops lol i just copied some code from up the top and thanks ill give it a look now [br][size=1]Posted on: February 22, 2007, 04:06:38 PM[/size][hr]like this? because it works with out the else but it dont skip the ones if it is / aint it

if(var3.equals("*")){ var1 = var1 * var2; } System.out.printf("answer %d\n", var1); else if(var3.equals("/")){ var1 = var1 / var2; } System.out.printf("answer %d\n", var1); else if(var3.equals("-")){ var1 = var1 - var2; } System.out.printf("answer %d\n", var1); else if(var3.equals("+")){ var1 = var1 + var2; } System.out.printf("answer %d\n", var1);

item.title: Little help please
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

one thing iv noticed

if (var3 == "*"){

that doesnt check if the Strings are the same, it only checks if they are stored in the same memory location
so it gives unpredictable results
String is an object to compair them, do it like this

if(var3.equals("*"))

if(var3.equalsIgnoreCase("*"))

try replacing printf with println

Read full topic

item.title: Little help please
item.dc:creator: @N00b1 N00b1
item.description:
@N00b1 wrote:

i cant get it to work

[code]import java.util.*;

//My calk

public class calk
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
// varibles

	int var1 = 0;
	int var2 = 0;
	String var3 = "";

	Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("******This is my new calculator v1.1****** \n");
	System.out.print("please enter your first number: ");
	var1 = in.nextInt();
	System.out.print("please enter your what you want to do with this number(* / - +): ");
	var3 = in.next();
	System.out.print("please enter your second number: ");
	var2 = in.nextInt();

	// workings out

	if (var3 == "*"){
		var1 = var1 * var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	if (var3 == "/"){
				var1 = var1 / var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	if (var3 == "-"){
						var1 = var1 - var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	if (var3 == "+"){
						var1 = var1 + var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	System.out.printf("sorry %d is not reconised please enter ether * / - +", var3);
}

}[/code]

did try this but then i get a load of compile errors

[code]import java.util.*;

//My calk

public class calk
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
// varibles

	int var1 = 0;
	int var2 = 0;
	String var3 = "";

	Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("******This is my new calculator v1.1****** \n");
	System.out.print("please enter your first number: ");
	var1 = in.nextInt();
	System.out.print("please enter your what you want to do with this number(* / - +): ");
	var3 = in.next();
	System.out.print("please enter your second number: ");
	var2 = in.nextInt();

	// workings out

	if (var3 == "*"){
		var1 = var1 * var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	else
	if (var3 == "/"){
				var1 = var1 / var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	else
	if (var3 == "-"){
						var1 = var1 - var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	else
	if (var3 == "+"){
						var1 = var1 + var2;
	}
	System.out.printf("answer %d", var1);
	else
	System.out.printf("sorry %d is not reconised please enter ether * / - +", var3);
}

}[/code]

its probably something easy but eh im lazy
